functional_evidence_assessment.functional_evidence_aim: To assess the pathogenicity of DJ-1 L166P mutation in Parkinson's disease
functional_evidence_assessment.assay_justification: The study uses a cellular model to determine if the expressed DJ-1 L166P mutant protein rescues the phenotype of cells treated with parkinsonism-inducing compounds, compared to wild-type and known pathogenic/benign control variants.
functional_evidence_assessment.assay_controls: Wild-type (WT) and known loss-of-function (LoF) DJ-1 mutant proteins are used as controls. The study also includes a cell line stably expressing the Parkin protein, which is known to cause autosomal recessive early-onset Parkinson's disease.
functional_evidence_assessment.assay_replicates: The experiments were performed in triplicate
functional_evidence_assessment.overall_conclusion: The DJ-1 L166P mutation causes a loss of function, as it fails to rescue the parkinsonism phenotype in cells and does not support cell survival under stress conditions. The strong evidence from the cell phenotype rescue assay supports a pathogenic role for this mutation in Parkinson's disease.
